data.title: News – Lake Land College
data.text:
Lake Land College Career Services is launching the Hire a Laker campaign, an opportunity for local businesses to collaborate with the College and promote their companies to job-seeking students.

Under the Hire a Laker campaign, the College is spotlighting local organizations with a history of hiring Lake Land alumni. Participating organizations will be featured on the Lake Land College Career Services webpage and social media platforms. Companies interested in joining the campaign can visit the Lake Land College Career Services webpage at LakeLandCollege.edu/Hire-a-Laker and complete the submission form.

“We’re very excited to foster connections with local businesses and spotlight their company values through this campaign,” said Stephanie Anderson, Internship & Employment Coordinator. “When we help our Lakers find rewarding, local careers, that’s a win for our students, the companies and our community.”

Lake Land College Career Services is a resource for local businesses to meet employment needs and find qualified workers for their organizations. Career Services supports employers by sharing job openings on Lake Land’s campus and social media pages, sending job opportunities to relevant departments and arranging on-campus recruitment sessions and job fairs. More information about Career Services, upcoming job fairs and on-campus recruiting opportunities is available on the Lake Land College website at LakeLandCollege.edu/Career-Services/Services-for-Employers/.

For more information about the Hire a Laker campaign or other opportunities with Lake Land Career Services, contact Anderson at 217-234-5457 or sfreeman41846@LakeLandCollege.edu.

-30-

Lake Land College is proud to announce that more than 800 part-time students earned academic honors for the 2024 Spring semester.

To qualify for the president’s list, a student must have completed six to 11 credit hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.8 – 4.0.

To qualify for the dean’s list, a student must have completed six to 11 credit hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.65 – 3.79.

To qualify for the honor’s list, a student must have completed six to 11 hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.5 – 3.64.

A grade “A” is four points, a “B” is three points, a “C” is two points, etc.

The following part-time students have achieved these academic honors:

-30-

Lake Land College is proud to announce that more than 800 full-time students earned academic honors for the 2024 Spring semester.

To qualify for the president’s list, a student must have completed at least 12 credit hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.8 – 4.0.

To qualify for the dean’s list, a student must have completed at least 12 credit hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.65 – 3.79.

To qualify for the honor’s list, a student must have completed at least 12 hours in courses numbered 040 or higher per semester, excluding summer term, with a GPA of 3.5 – 3.64.

A grade “A” is four points, a “B” is three points, a “C” is two points, etc.

The following full-time students have achieved these academic honors:

As a part of its commitment to developing and maintaining a diverse, inclusive campus environment for students, staff and faculty, Lake Land College is recognizing and celebrating Pride month throughout June.

“It’s so important for us as a college to celebrate all our students and offer the support they need to be the best, most authentic versions of themselves,” said Mercury Bowen, Coordinator for Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and Belonging. “We are pleased to recognize all LGBTQIA+ individuals in our community by celebrating Pride month.”

As the DEIB Coordinator, Bowen serves as an advocate for student needs, leading initiatives that maintain a positive campus environment and reflect a diverse student population. Included in these efforts are a wide variety of Pride and LGBTQ+ resources, such as a campus club, ally training programs and funding sources to help with identity changes.

The campus Pride club is dedicated to promoting understanding and equity for the LGBTQIA+ community. LGBTQIA+ individuals as well as allies are invited to join and support an inclusive campus environment. Current students can learn more and register to join the club by visiting the Lake Land College club webpage at LakeLandCollege.edu/student-life/clubs/.

Lake Land also offers a Safe Zone training program, implemented by the Inclusion, Diversity & Equity Committee to welcome and support members of the LGBTQIA+ community at the College. The tiered program offers three levels of training intensity; Ally, Advocate and Trainer; and equips participants with the knowledge they need to provide a safe, supportive place for all individuals. A modified version of the training called “Safe with Me” is also available for students.

The LGBTQIA+ Reserve Fund also provides immediate assistance to LGBTQIA+ students at Lake Land College. Funds are used to help transgender students legally change their names and help protect their identities. More information on how to donate to the fund or how to apply for support is available on the Lake Land College website at LakeLandCollege.edu/diversity/safe-zone/.

Additional resources for LGBTQIA+ members and allies are available on the Lake Land College website at LakeLandCollege.edu/diversity/safe-zone/.

For more information on inclusion, diversity and equity at Lake Land College, visit the Lake Land College diversity webpage at LakeLandCollege.edu/diversity.

-30-

Lake Land College announced the hiring of Kristi Paulson as the new Laker softball head coach during the Board of Trustees meeting on Monday, June 10. Her husband, Dan Paulson, is expected to join the staff as the co-head coach following the next board meeting in July.

A Mattoon native, Kristi Paulson played softball for two years at Lake Land College. She helped the Laker softball team win its first NJCAA Division I National Tournament during the 2005-2006 season. After transferring to Eastern Illinois University, she served as a volunteer assistant softball coach at Lake Land.

“I’m grateful for this opportunity and I’m excited to be back coaching in my hometown,” Paulson said. “I’m looking forward to creating a positive environment that allows our players to grow as both athletes and people and challenges them to be greater than they ever thought they could be.”

Paulson brings an extensive history of coaching experience to the Lake Land College position. She previously served as the softball coach at Casey-Westfield Junior High School and the assistant softball coach at Tuscola High School. She has also coached competitive summer and travel softball teams, mentoring high school-aged players with aspirations of playing in college. In 2011, she and her husband created Premier Fastpitch, an elite travel softball program for youth and high school athletes. Under the Paulsons’ leadership, Premier Fastpitch has competed on both state and national levels with a 0.738 winning percentage.

In 2018, Kristi Paulson joined the Parkland College softball coaching staff, and she and her husband were named the team’s co-head coaches in 2019. During their five seasons as co-head coaches, the Paulsons led the Cobras to a 0.785 winning percentage (205-56). They also won three Central District Championships and four consecutive Mid-West Athletic Conference titles during that span and secured two top-eight finishes in the NJCAA DII National Championship. The 2023-2024 Cobras softball team was named the top-ranked Division II team in the country and secured the number one seed in the NJCAA DII Softball World Series tournament.

The Paulsons received the Mid-West Athletic Conference Coach of the Year Award four consecutive years from 2021 to 2024 and are three-time recipients of the Region 24 Coach of the Year Award. In 2024, they were named coaches of the year for the Midwest Region and at the national level by the National Fastpitch Coaches Association.

“We’re excited to welcome Kristi back to Lake Land College,” said Bill Jackson, Director of Athletics. “She and Dan built an unbelievable winning culture at Parkland College, and we are excited for them to bring that culture to Lake Land College softball.”

-30-

Lake Land College will host an Introduction to Nursing event on Tuesday, July 23 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. in Neal Hall. The event is designed for high school students to learn about careers in nursing and gain valuable tips on the nursing special admission process.

During the event, participating students will learn about available nursing programs at Lake Land College and discover career opportunities in the field. They will also meet with program faculty and alumni, tour Lake Land’s facilities and receive hands-on experience in the College’s high-fidelity simulation lab.

Space for the Introduction to Nursing event is limited to the first 30 registrants. Registration is open now on the Lake Land College visit page at LakeLandCollege.edu/visit.

For more information, contact Nichole Jones, Nursing Instructor, at 217-234-5455 or njones8307@lakelandcollege.edu.

-30-

Lake Land College will host Laker Visit Day on Thursday, June 13 from 9 a.m. to noon in the Luther Student Center. The event is designed for prospective students to learn about Lake Land College and how the Laker Advantage can guide them on the path to success.

Attendees will tour campus with a Laker representative, who will share insights about the College. Participants will also meet with faculty to learn more about specific programs.

Representatives from many services, including Counseling Services, Career Services, Student Accommodations, Student Wellness, TRIO Student Support Services and more will be available to provide information and answer attendees’ questions.

Attendees are also welcome to bring their parents or guardians to the event. A session will be offered to provide relevant information to parents or guardians of future Lakers.

“If you’re interested in attending Lake Land College, Laker Visit Day is the perfect event for you,” Pam Hartke, associate dean of enrollment, said. “There’s no better way to learn about our campus resources and get a feel for the College as a whole.”

For more information or to register, visit the Lake Land College visit page at lakelandcollege.edu/visit.

-30-
